chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: Today we'll be talking about risk stratification.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: After giving you a broad overview

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: of what I mean by risk stratification,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: I'm going to give you a case study, which

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: you read about in your readings for today's lecture,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: coming from early detection of type 2 diabetes.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And I won't be, of course, repeating

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: the same material you heard you write about in your readings.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: Rather, I'll be giving some interesting color around what

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: are some of the questions that we

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: need to be thinking about as machine learning people

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: when we try to apply machine learning to problems like this.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: Then I'll talk about some of the subtleties, what

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: can go wrong with machine learning-based approaches

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: to risk stratification.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And finally, the last half of today's lecture

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: is going to be a discussion.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: So about 3 PM, you'll see a man walk through the door.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: His name is Leonard Davolio.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: He is a professor at Brigham and Women's Hospital.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: He also has a startup company called

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: SIFT, which is working on applying risk stratification

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: now.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And they have lots of clients.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And they've been really deep in the details

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: of how to make this stuff work.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And so we'll have an interview between myself and him.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And we'll have opportunity for all of you

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: to ask questions as well.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And I think that's what I hope will

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: be the most exciting part of today's lecture.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: Then going on beyond today's lecture,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: we are now in the beginning of a sequence of three lectures

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: on very similar topics.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: So next Thursday, we'll be talking about survival

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: modeling.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And you can think about it as an extension of today's lecture,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: talking about what you should do if your data has centering,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: which I'll define for you shortly.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: Although today's lecture is going to be a little bit more

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: high level, next Thursday's lecture

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: is where we're going to really start to get

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: into mathematical details about how

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: one should tackle machine learning

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: problems with censored data.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And then the following lecture after that

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: is going to be on physiological data.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And that lecture will also be much more technical in nature

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: compared to the first couple of weeks of the course.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: So what is risk stratification?

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: At a high level, you think about risk stratification

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: as a way of taking in a patient population

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: and separating out all of your patients

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: into one of two or more categories,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: patients with high risk, patients with low risk,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: and maybe patients somewhere in the middle.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: Now, the reason why we might want to do risk stratification

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: is because we usually want to try

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: to act on those predictions.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: So the goals are often one of coupling those predictions

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: with known interventions.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: So for example, patients in the high risk pool,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: we will attempt to do something for those patients

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: to prevent whatever that outcome is of interest from occurring.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: Now, risk stratification is quite different from diagnosis.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: Diagnosis often has very, very stringent criteria

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: on performance.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: If you do a misdiagnosis of something,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: that can have very severe consequences

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: in terms of patients being treated for conditions

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: that they didn't need to be treated for and patients

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: dying because they were not diagnosed in time.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: Now, risk stratification, you think

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: of it as a little bit more fuzzy in nature.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: We want to do our best job of trying

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: to push patients into each of these categories,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: high risk, low risk, and so on.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And as I'll show you throughout today's lecture,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: the performance characteristics that we'll often care about

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: are going to be a bit different.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: We're going to look a bit more at quantities

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: such as positive predictive value.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: Are we finding of the patients we say are high risk,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: what fraction of them are actually high risk?

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And in that way, it differs a bit from diagnosis.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: Also, as a result of the goals being different,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: the data that's used is often very different.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: In risk stratification, often we use

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: data which is very diverse.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: So you might bring in multiple views of a patient.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: You might use auxiliary data such as patient's demographics,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: maybe even socioeconomic information about a patient,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: all of which very much affect their risk profiles

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: but may not be used for an unbiased diagnosis of a patient.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And finally, in today's economic environment,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: risk stratification is very much targeted

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: towards reducing cost of the US health care setting.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And so I'll give you a few examples of risk stratification,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: some of which have cost as a major goal, others which don't.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: The first example is that of predicting an infant's

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: risk of severe morbidity.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: So this is a premature baby.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: My niece, for example, was born three months premature.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: It was really scary for my sister and for my whole family.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And the outcomes of patients who were born premature

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: have really changed dramatically over the last century.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And now, patients who were born three months premature,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: like my niece, actually can survive and do really well

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: in terms of long-term outcomes.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: But of the many different inventions

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: that led to these improved outcomes, one of them

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: was having a very good understanding

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: of how risky a particular infant might be.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: So a very common score that's used

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: to try to characterize risk for infant birth,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: generally speaking, is known as the Apgar score.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And for example, when my son was born,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: I was really excited when a few seconds after my son

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: was delivered, the nurse took out a piece of paper

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: and computed the Apgar score.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: I was like, oh, I studied that.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: Really interesting, right?

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And then I got back to some of the other things that I had to.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: But that score isn't actually as accurate as it could be.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And there is this paper, which we'll talk about actually

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: in a week and a half, by Suchi Surya,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: who's a professor at Johns Hopkins, which

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: looked at how one could use a machine learning-based approach

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: to really improve our ability to predict morbidity in infants.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: Another example, which I'm pulling from the readings

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: from today's lecture, has to do with,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: for patients who come into the emergency department

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: with a heart-related condition, trying to understand,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: do they need to be admitted to the coronary care unit?

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: Or is it safe enough to let that patient go home and be managed

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: by their primary care physician or their cardiologist

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: outside of the hospital setting?

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: Now, that paper, you might have all noticed, was from 1984.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: So this isn't a new concept.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And moreover, if you look at the amount of data

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: that they used in that study, it was over 2,000 patients.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: They had a nontrivial number of variables,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: 50-something variables.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And they used a nontrivial machine learning algorithm.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: They used logistic regression with a feature selection

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: built in to prevent themselves from overfitting

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: to the data.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And the goal there was very much cost-oriented.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: So the premise was that if one could quickly

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: decide these patients who've just come to the ER

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: are not high risk and we can send them home,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: then we'll be able to reduce the large amount of cost

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: associated with those admissions to coronary care units.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And the final example I'll give right now

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: is that of predicting likelihood of hospital readmission.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: So this is something which is getting

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: a real lot of attention in the United States health care

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: space over the last few years because of penalties

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: which the US government has imposed

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: on hospitals who have a large number of patients who

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: have been released from the hospital and then

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: within the next 30 days readmitted to the hospital.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And that's part of the transition to value-based care,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: which Pete mentioned in earlier lectures.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And so the premise is that there are many patients who

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: are hospitalized but are not managed appropriately

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: on discharge or after discharge.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: For example, maybe this patient who has a heart condition

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: wasn't really clear on what they should

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: have done when they go home.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: For example, what medications should they be taking?

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: When should they follow up with their cardiologist?

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: What things they should be looking out

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: for in terms of warning signs that they should go back

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: to the hospital or call their doctor for?

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And as a result of that poor communication,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: it's conjectured that these poor outcomes might occur.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: So if we could figure out which of the patients

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: are likely to have those readmissions,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: then we could change the way.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And if we could do those, if we could

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: predict that while the patients are still in the hospital,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: then we could change the way that discharge is done.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: For example, we could send a nurse or a social worker

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: to talk to the patient, go really slowly

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: through the discharge instructions.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: Maybe after the patient is discharged,

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: one could have a nurse follow up at the patient's home

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: over the next few weeks.

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: And in this way, hopefully reduce

chunks.title: Lecture 4 Risk Stratification, Part 1
chunks.text: the likelihood of that readmission.

text: Today we'll be talking about risk stratification. After giving you a broad overview of what I mean by risk stratification, I'm going to give you a case study, which you read about in your readings for today's lecture, coming from early detection of type 2 diabetes. And I won't be, of course, repeating the same material you heard you write about in your readings. Rather, I'll be giving some interesting color around what are some of the questions that we need to be thinking about as machine learning people when we try to apply machine learning to problems like this. Then I'll talk about some of the subtleties, what can go wrong with machine learning-based approaches to risk stratification. And finally, the last half of today's lecture is going to be a discussion. So about 3 PM, you'll see a man walk through the door. His name is Leonard Davolio. He is a professor at Brigham and Women's Hospital. He also has a startup company called SIFT, which is working on applying risk stratification now. And they have lots of clients. And they've been really deep in the details of how to make this stuff work. And so we'll have an interview between myself and him. And we'll have opportunity for all of you to ask questions as well. And I think that's what I hope will be the most exciting part of today's lecture. Then going on beyond today's lecture, we are now in the beginning of a sequence of three lectures on very similar topics. So next Thursday, we'll be talking about survival modeling. And you can think about it as an extension of today's lecture, talking about what you should do if your data has centering, which I'll define for you shortly. Although today's lecture is going to be a little bit more high level, next Thursday's lecture is where we're going to really start to get into mathematical details about how one should tackle machine learning problems with censored data. And then the following lecture after that is going to be on physiological data. And that lecture will also be much more technical in nature compared to the first couple of weeks of the course. So what is risk stratification? At a high level, you think about risk stratification as a way of taking in a patient population and separating out all of your patients into one of two or more categories, patients with high risk, patients with low risk, and maybe patients somewhere in the middle. Now, the reason why we might want to do risk stratification is because we usually want to try to act on those predictions. So the goals are often one of coupling those predictions with known interventions. So for example, patients in the high risk pool, we will attempt to do something for those patients to prevent whatever that outcome is of interest from occurring. Now, risk stratification is quite different from diagnosis. Diagnosis often has very, very stringent criteria on performance. If you do a misdiagnosis of something, that can have very severe consequences in terms of patients being treated for conditions that they didn't need to be treated for and patients dying because they were not diagnosed in time. Now, risk stratification, you think of it as a little bit more fuzzy in nature. We want to do our best job of trying to push patients into each of these categories, high risk, low risk, and so on. And as I'll show you throughout today's lecture, the performance characteristics that we'll often care about are going to be a bit different. We're going to look a bit more at quantities such as positive predictive value. Are we finding of the patients we say are high risk, what fraction of them are actually high risk? And in that way, it differs a bit from diagnosis. Also, as a result of the goals being different, the data that's used is often very different. In risk stratification, often we use data which is very diverse. So you might bring in multiple views of a patient. You might use auxiliary data such as patient's demographics, maybe even socioeconomic information about a patient, all of which very much affect their risk profiles but may not be used for an unbiased diagnosis of a patient. And finally, in today's economic environment, risk stratification is very much targeted towards reducing cost of the US health care setting. And so I'll give you a few examples of risk stratification, some of which have cost as a major goal, others which don't. The first example is that of predicting an infant's risk of severe morbidity. So this is a premature baby. My niece, for example, was born three months premature. It was really scary for my sister and for my whole family. And the outcomes of patients who were born premature have really changed dramatically over the last century. And now, patients who were born three months premature, like my niece, actually can survive and do really well in terms of long-term outcomes. But of the many different inventions that led to these improved outcomes, one of them was having a very good understanding of how risky a particular infant might be. So a very common score that's used to try to characterize risk for infant birth, generally speaking, is known as the Apgar score. And for example, when my son was born, I was really excited when a few seconds after my son was delivered, the nurse took out a piece of paper and computed the Apgar score. I was like, oh, I studied that. Really interesting, right? And then I got back to some of the other things that I had to. But that score isn't actually as accurate as it could be. And there is this paper, which we'll talk about actually in a week and a half, by Suchi Surya, who's a professor at Johns Hopkins, which looked at how one could use a machine learning-based approach to really improve our ability to predict morbidity in infants. Another example, which I'm pulling from the readings from today's lecture, has to do with, for patients who come into the emergency department with a heart-related condition, trying to understand, do they need to be admitted to the coronary care unit? Or is it safe enough to let that patient go home and be managed by their primary care physician or their cardiologist outside of the hospital setting? Now, that paper, you might have all noticed, was from 1984. So this isn't a new concept. And moreover, if you look at the amount of data that they used in that study, it was over 2,000 patients. They had a nontrivial number of variables, 50-something variables. And they used a nontrivial machine learning algorithm. They used logistic regression with a feature selection built in to prevent themselves from overfitting to the data. And the goal there was very much cost-oriented. So the premise was that if one could quickly decide these patients who've just come to the ER are not high risk and we can send them home, then we'll be able to reduce the large amount of cost associated with those admissions to coronary care units. And the final example I'll give right now is that of predicting likelihood of hospital readmission. So this is something which is getting a real lot of attention in the United States health care space over the last few years because of penalties which the US government has imposed on hospitals who have a large number of patients who have been released from the hospital and then within the next 30 days readmitted to the hospital. And that's part of the transition to value-based care, which Pete mentioned in earlier lectures. And so the premise is that there are many patients who are hospitalized but are not managed appropriately on discharge or after discharge. For example, maybe this patient who has a heart condition wasn't really clear on what they should have done when they go home. For example, what medications should they be taking? When should they follow up with their cardiologist? What things they should be looking out for in terms of warning signs that they should go back to the hospital or call their doctor for? And as a result of that poor communication, it's conjectured that these poor outcomes might occur. So if we could figure out which of the patients are likely to have those readmissions, then we could change the way. And if we could do those, if we could predict that while the patients are still in the hospital, then we could change the way that discharge is done. For example, we could send a nurse or a social worker to talk to the patient, go really slowly through the discharge instructions. Maybe after the patient is discharged, one could have a nurse follow up at the patient's home over the next few weeks. And in this way, hopefully reduce the likelihood of that readmission.
